Director, Regulatory Management Division
US Citizenship and Immigration Services
Department of Homeland Security
111 Massachusetts Ave. NW, 3rd floor
Washington DC 20529.

RE: DHS Docket # USCIS-2006-0044
Proposed rule? Adjustment of the Immigration and Naturalization Benefit Application
and Petition Fee Schedule

The National Immigration Forum submits the following comment regarding the fee
increase proposed for immigration benefits in the proposed rule published in the
Federal Register on February 1. The National Immigration Forum opposes the fee
increases and urges USCIS to seek Congressional appropriations to cover additional
costs.

The National Immigration Forum advocates and builds support for public policies that
welcome immigrants and refugees and are fair and supportive to America?s newcomers
and the communities in which they settle. As part of its mission, the Forum promotes
policies to encourage immigrants to become fully integrated into American society.

As such, we are concerned that the steep fee increases proposed by USCIS will serve
as a barrier and prevent eligible immigrants from taking the necessary steps to become
citizens. The proposed adjustment of status fee (including the biometric fee and
required medical examination) would exceed $1,000. This would amount to a full
month?s pay for a minimum wage worker and would effectively price him or her out of
being able to adjust to become a legal permanent resident, and thus a citizen later. The
fees for naturalizing are equally exorbitant. Should the proposed fee go into effect, the
increase in the naturalization application fee will be 710% in 10 years. Similar steep
rises are proposed to go into effect for other immigration benefits.

It is in our nation?s interest and consistent with our tradition as a nation of immigrants to
encourage, rather than discourage, immigrant integration and citizenship. The
proposed fee increase moves us in the wrong direction.

Interim Benefits Costs Should Not be Included in the I-485 Fee

Because many adjustment applicants do not file for interim benefits such as
employment authorization (i.e. minors do not need this, neither do many asylees who
have work authorization) or advance parole (many people choose not to travel during
this period, many others cannot do so without triggering inadmissibility bars) it is
patently unfair to charge all adjustment applicants for a benefit which many will not
need.

Fee waivers should not be eliminated for entire groups of applicants

USICS proposes to eliminate fee waivers for certain forms, stating that applicants are
supposed to show that they will not become a public charge, and applying for a fee
waiver contradicts this requirement. However, not all applicants using the forms listed
in the proposed rule are required to show they will not become a public charge?for
instance, asylees applying to adjust their status, as well as persons seeking to adjust
based on the Cuban Adjustment Act and NACARA, are exempt from the public charge
grounds of inadmissibility.

In addition, by waiving the fee on a blanket basis for VAWA I-360 petitions but
simultaneously eliminating the possibility of a fee waiver for adjustment applicants, the
Service is actually making it more difficult for this vulnerable group of applicants. A
VAWA petitioner will be spared the $375 fee but be barred from seeking a waiver for
the proposed $905 fee to adjust her status. It would be more equitable and humane to
have both waivers continue to be available.

The cost of modernizing the agency should not be borne entirely by immigrants

USCIS has in recent years obtained appropriated funds from Congress so it could
make investments needed to reduce application backlogs. We urge USCIS to continue
to seek appropriated funds for some of the expenses described in the proposed rule.

Immigration benefits our entire country and we as a nation should help pay for it.
Immigrants help revitalize our communities and our economy. We should be
encouraging immigrants to become part of our community by gaining legal status and
becoming citizens. We should not be setting up barriers to block their path and keep
them out, which is what this dramatic fee increase would do.

We stand ready to work with USCIS to seek additional Congressional funding for
adjudication and infrastructure costs but believe it is imperative for USCIS to step up to
the plate and affirmatively seek necessary appropriations to carry out these functions.
Unless this happens, the proposed fee increase will go into effect and many deserving
and qualified immigrants will be shut out of the process of becoming citizens and fully
integrated into our society.

Conclusion

In sum, we urge USICS to reconsider the proposed fee increases, to examine its costs
more closely, and to seek Congressional appropriations for enhancements and
modernization. Thank you for your consideration of these comments.

Sincerely,

Christina DeConcini, Esq.
Director of Policy

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
